The one with "developing mindset" believes they can cultivate their passion in the given job or context. 78% of people have the "fit mindset" according to this book.&nbsp;</p><p>In the beginning, the one with "fit mindset" has higher "fit" feeling but later the one with "developing mindset" will catch up with them.&nbsp;</p><p><b>The important point here is there is a way to cultivate your passion.&nbsp;</b></p><p><br></p><h3>Apply to a writing&nbsp;</h3><p>Let me also apply this "developing mindset" to writing.   'title': 'Sleep Debt',
  'content': '<blockquote><b>Sleep debt</b> or sleep deficit is the cumulative effect of not getting enough sleep. A large sleep debt may lead to mental or physical fatigue. –wikipedia</blockquote><p>This term "sleep debt" was prposed by Professor William C. Dement at Sanford. Nobody likes "debt" in any area. I think this is a good naminig to alarmingly emphasize how important to have sufficient sleep.</p><p>Today I would like to explain about the concept of sleep debt and how difficult to return this debt.&nbsp;</p><p><br></p><h3>Why it is a problem?</h3><p>One of the trick characteristics for sleep debt is that we tend not to recognize this cumulative sleep debt. We might think we sleep sufficiently everyday and there is no sleep issue. However, there might be a chance that you do have slightly lower than you need everyday. That difference would be <b>accumulated like a snow ball</b> of financial debt with interest. Without our noticing, our performance of work or chore jobs are decreased. In the worst case, you might be dead due to the mistakes or sickness trigered by lack of sleep.&nbsp;</p><p>One research by University of Pennsylvania (<a href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12683469" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">The cumulative cost of additional wakefulness</a>)&nbsp;showed one intriging result:&nbsp;</p><ul><li>The performance of those who stay over the night dropped sharply</li><li>The performance of <b>those who sleep less (6 hours) everyday for 2 weeks</b> eventually became equivalent to the one of <b>those who stay over the night on the 2nd day</b>.</li></ul><p><br></p><h3>How to detect sleep debt?</h3><p>It is actually difficult but if you need to sleep a lot on weekend or your days off, this could be the indicator of sleep debt. Your brain and body thrive to return the sleep debt cumulated during the weekdays.&nbsp;</p><p>To test it, you should sleep in a completely dark room without PC or smartphones\' screen. When you wake up but still feel like sleepy, sleep again until it goes away. If you observe <b>the increase of sleep time more than 2 hours</b>, you need to re-consider your sleep schedule.&nbsp;</p><p><br></p><p>&nbsp; &nbsp;</p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p>\r\n        \r\n    ',

  'content': '<p>Trie [ˈtriː]&nbsp; is also called "prefix tree", which is one type of tree structure where each node stores all values in the descendants. In other words, all the descendants of a node have a common prefix. That is why it is called "prefix tree."</p><p>For example, let\'s say we have a tree like below:</p><p>&nbsp;- a - ap - app - appl - apple&nbsp;</p><p>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; - ap - app</p><p>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;- apo - apol - apolo</p><p>Note that the root is typically empty.&nbsp;</p><p><br></p><p>As you can see above, this structure can be seen somewhere in daily life. It is in a dictionary. When you are finding a word, you need to follow a trie structure.&nbsp;</p><p><br></p><h3>What is good for?</h3><p>Trie is good for searching. It is very efficient in the worst case scenario where you have bad luck and end up with looking up all nodes while searching.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p>As for application, this is useful to predict the next text or autocomplete dictionary where we also usually use when you type a few words and google or keyboard software suggests the next words.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><h3>Limitation</h3><p>Trie can be slower and would require more memory space than hash tables in some cases.&nbsp;</p><p><br></p><p>Last Saturday, I joined the coding contest and solved the difficult problem but I did not feel like it was the best solution. A friend of mine gave me a hint that maybe we should use a trie, which I did not know yet. This is good to learn.&nbsp;</p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p>\r\n        \r\n    ',

It is also an ability to find it difficult"</i></li></ul><p></p><p><br></p><p>***</p><p>To build a habit, I found it very powerful to have an appropriate mindset and the right strategy. So let me try to explain it.</p><p>In my understanding, Murphy\'s law is that ones tend to believe something happens more likely <b>only when something bad or unusual happens. </b>This is because ones remember more vividly because of such a bad thing. Our brain is designed to store the memory which has more meanings, changes, surprises, not boring, not normal things to avoid storing meaningless information.</p><p>Thanks to this law, there exists a lot of humor.&nbsp; One of the famous ones is&nbsp;</p><blockquote>The chance of the bread falling with the buttered side down is directly proportional to the cost of the carpet.</blockquote><p>Different variations related to our life are as follows:</p><ul><li>The areas that I studied was not asked in the exam but only the area I did not study was asked.&nbsp;</li><li>Only when I brought an umbrella, it did not rain.&nbsp;</li><li>Only when I tried to use a printer, the printer is not working</li><li>At the last moment when I thought my work was completed, I found a mistake.</li><li>When I tried to prove it was not working, it started to work.&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;</li></ul><p><br></p><p>Do you have your version of Murphy\'s law?</p><p><br></p><p>Hiro</p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p>&nbsp;</p><p><br></p><p>&nbsp;</p><p><br></p><p>&nbsp;</p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p>\r\n    \r\n    \r\n    \r\n    \r\n    \r\n    \r\n    ',

  'content': "<p>DFS–depth-first search is one of the algorithms to explore the tree nodes where you first deep dive the tree and branches towards the end of the tree, i.e., the leaves.&nbsp;</p><p>For example, let's think of the organization chart in a company as a tree where it assumes a&nbsp;boss or manager has one or more subordinates. If you need to look up your name,&nbsp;</p><p>1) the depth-first search will start from the CEO, which is the root of your org tree.&nbsp;</p><p>2) Then pick up one of those under him/her to check if the person is you or not.&nbsp;</p><p>3) If not, we keep doing the same until reaching to the person who does not have any associates, which we call John in this example.&nbsp;</p><p>4) Then, just go up one layer i.e., John's boss and look for one of his or her colleagues, Mary. If she has subordinates, we will investigate their names one by one.&nbsp;</p><p>Repeat the above steps from 2) to 4) until we find the target name.</p><p><br></p><p>This depth-first search can be useful and powerful when you would like to find the following things:&nbsp;</p><ul><li>Find the path of a maze = I believe when you actually try to solve a maze, people typically do the depth-first search.</li><li>Find the connected cities by trains or airplane&nbsp;</li></ul><p><br></p><p><br></p><p>***&nbsp;</p><p>Grammarly: 5</p><p>Word of the day:&nbsp;arduous, hard to accomplish</p><p><br></p><p><br></p>\r\n        \r\n    ",

  'title': 'FT13 Boosting',
  'content': '<p>Boosting is one of the machine learning approaches or meta-algorithms to make a stronger prediction by using a collective power of weaker predictions. When you train the model, we use a part of the training data to train a weak predictor and learn the mistakes. Based on this mistake, we use the lesson learned to train the next predictor to make it a bit stronger and smarter. Repeating this exercise, we will get which weak predictor has better performance in general. Then when we make the final decision, we will use this weight as balancing the result from weak learners.&nbsp;</p><p>In a way, a group of people such as organizations, companies can be a collection of neural networks i.e., human brains. We make a lot of decisions by reflecting on members\' opinions or preference indirectly or directly. In theory, even if each member is not that smart, overall if we have enough people and a number of repetition, we have a higher chance to make a better decision than an average one.&nbsp;</p><p>Based on this meta-algorithm, many powerful algorithms have been generated such as Random Forest and Gradient&nbsp;Boosting.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p>Personally, I like this idea to combine the&nbsp;collective opinions and then get a&nbsp;better result. It sounded a power of democracy. One might think society should be led by only smartest people but that works on a certain condition. It might be overfitted to the current or recent condition. To avoid overfitting, we should still need diversity and even "weak" members, which is measured in one aspect but we will not know that this is actually weak or not.&nbsp;</p><p><br></p><p>***</p><p>Grammarly: 4</p><p>Word of the day:&nbsp;comminute</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p>&nbsp;</p><p><br></p><p><br></p>',

  'title': 'Correlation is not causality',
  'content': '\r\n        \r\n        <br><p>One of the typical mistakes in statistics or data analysis is "correlation is interpretted as causality." In other words, if we find the correlation between A and B, and it seems as A increases, B also increases as well. Let\'s look at the cases below:</p><ul><li>The students with higher SAT score has more stamina.&nbsp;</li><li>&nbsp;As the number of doctors per person increases in a region, the medical costs increases in the region.</li><li>Those who take annual checkups has less chances of diabetes.&nbsp;</li></ul><p>For the first example, this correlation cannot be interpretted as "<b>because </b>the student has higher SAT score, they can have more stamina." Based on this wrong interpretation, ones can derive the conclusion that ones need to make the students SAT score higher in order to increase their stamina.&nbsp;</p><p>We need to be careful for some cases where correlation looks causality as below.</p><ul><li>Common factor*</li><li>Pure luck**</li></ul><p>If both phenomena can be caused by another factor in common, two phenoma looks correlated and seems to have the causal relationship. In the above example, if they mixed all students across grades, the common factor might be the age of the students. As they grow, they get smater and gain more stamina.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p>For the second part, the two phenena purely conincidentally seems to have correlation. You can find a lot but ridiculously correlated examples in <a href="http://www.tylervigen.com/spurious-correlations" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">here</a>. In this website, you can find the highly correlated examples between:</p><ul><li>US spending on science, space and tech vs suicides by hanging</li><li># of drowned people&nbsp;in a pool vs Films Nicolas Cage appeared in</li><li>Cheese consumption vs # of people who died due to bedsheets</li></ul><p><br></p><p><br></p><p>*this is callsed "confounding factor"</p><p>** this is called "sprious correlation"</p><p><br></p><p>-------------</p><p>Word of the day:&nbsp;litmus test, in which has one single dominant facotor.</p>\r\n        \r\n    \r\n    \r\n    ',

  'title': 'FT12 Cross Validation ',
  'content': '<p>In a Machine Learning field, <i>Cross Validation</i>&nbsp;is a very important process. Today I will try to explain this concept with simpler terms and an example.&nbsp;</p><p>Cross Validation is an important process to ensure the model performance or the quality of learnings as the word "validation" says. If we say "the model performance is good," we woud like to believe the model perform well in general and believe this performance test is not cheating. How can we check and ensure the quality of learning?&nbsp;</p><p>Let\'s take an example by imagining a student, John and we are a teacher. Assuming John does not know 2 digit addition e.g., 11 + 20, 38 + 2 so we start with creating 50 exmaples of 2 digit addition as below.&nbsp;</p><p>2 + 9 = 11<br>4 + 11 = 15<br>12 + 32 = 34<br>83 + 29 = 112<br>.... etc.&nbsp;</p><p>He learned how to solve 2 digit addition. How can we test his learning if he fully understand 2 digit addition, not just remembering the pair of left parts and their answer respectively? Yes, you are right. As we grow up, we should give him "unseen" exercises to him and see if he can solve them or not so that we can see if he essencially understand the addition. This part is <i>validation.&nbsp;</i></p><p>Back to machine learning. In a machine learning world, we cannot easily create another new exercise since it might be computationally or economically expensive to create new one. Instead, in the above case, we just randomly pick and save 10 equations (approximately 20%) in the beginning, and let John to practice using the rest of equations (80%) repeatedly, which we call <i>training set</i>. Then we can test him using the 10 equation that we saved for testing purpose, which we call <i>test set</i>. Note that we should not have any duplicated equations in training and test set because we cannot tell if John literally memorize the answer or not.&nbsp;</p><p>Now let\'s move on <b style="font-style: italic;">"cross"&nbsp;</b>in Cross Validation. As a teacher, we would like to be very sure that John fully understands 2 digit addition if John can solve more than 8 out of 10 equations in a test set. However, in some cases, maybe because the test is extremely easy for him and 10 equations is almost close to 1 digit addition like 10 + 1, 10 +2, 20 + 3. To avoid this kind of lucky for John or unlucky for us, we test him with different test selection. If John were to forget everything a week later, we can test him using different training set, and see the test result by using different test set. By repeating this, we can observe if John can solve 80% of equations in a test, we can safely conclude that John learned 2 digit equations 80% accuracy.</p><p><br></p><p>There is some technically inaccurate part in the example but I hope this will help to get some intuition about cross validation. As a part of Feynman technique, I find the last part is more shaky. With this John\'s example, it is limited to explain the repetition. I should have chosen the other example.&nbsp;</p>',

  'title': 'FT10 Preorder (Tree Traversals)',
  'content': '<p>In Tree structure to explain the logical relationship, there are multiple ways to track the nodes across a tree. One of the methods of tracking a node is called "Preorder." Today I would like to explain it with as simple terminology as possible.</p><p><i><b>Preorder</b></i> is the way of tracing the node to tell someone to identify the exact tree in their mind.&nbsp;</p><p>Let\'s say if there&nbsp;is one pizza with 4 different taste. If I would like to tell the order of taste to somebody, I could tell I am calling the tastes "counterclockwise" so that another person can imagine the same pizza if I call out "Margherita, Veggie, Hawaiian,&nbsp;Mediterranean." Similarly, if I say I call out the tree nodes "1, 2, 4, 5, 3" using "preorder traversals", somebody should also imagine the same shape of a tree.</p><h3>Why it is called Pre-order??</h3><p>To traverse a node, there is 3 type of different processes at each node.&nbsp;</p><ul><li>L - Check the left subtree</li><li>R - Check the right subtree</li><li>N - Check the node itself</li></ul><p>Pre-order means "check the node itself \'<i><b>before</b></i>\' left and right subtrees."</p><p>So based on the order of these 3 steps, there are other 3 different order: Post-order (LRN), in-order (LNR), out-order (RNL).</p><p>If the nodes of a binary tree, where each node only can have 2 nodes, can be described as [1, 2, 4, 5, 3, null, null] in preorder traversal expression, what kind of tree does look like?&nbsp;</p><p>1 - root node</p><p>2 - left node under the root node</p><p>4 - left node under the left node of the root node</p><p>5 -&nbsp;right node under the left node of the root node</p><p>3 - right node under the root node</p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p>***&nbsp;</p><p>Grammarly: 2</p>',

But originally I assume this is coming from computer science.&nbsp;</p><p><br></p><h3>Bit</h3><p>Bit is a smallest unit of information. Usually it indicates if the information exists or the information does not exists. To indicate the two status of information existence, we decided to use a number: 0 and 1. Zero (0) means nothing. One (1) means there is something.&nbsp;</p><p>Now when it is a sequence of information, we can also express such a sequence using a sequence of zero or one e.g., 01110.&nbsp;</p><p><br></p><h3>Binary</h3><p>Now we saw the expression of a sequence of bit e.g., 01110. This expression is called <i>binary</i>. For each digit, there exists only 0 or 1. In our daily life, we only use <i>decimal</i>, which is another expression of information and uses from 0 to 9, in total 10 different numbers.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p><br></p><h3>Bit Magic</h3><p>Bit magic or bitwise algorithm means the problem is solved by taking an advantage of bit characteristics. One of the simplest example is to judege whether the number is odd or even number. If it is odd, the last digit is always odd. If it is even, the last digit is always even. So even if hundreds thousands of a sequence of bits, we only need the last digit to determine if this number is odd or even number.</p><p><br></p><p>&nbsp;</p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p>&nbsp;</p>",

  'title': 'FT8 Backtracking',
  'content': '\r\n        <p>Backtracking is one of the genral computer science algorithm to find a solution by try and error. I was not sure this can be called if this is algorithm.&nbsp;</p><p>At the beginning, I misunderstood this is the same as a brute-force approach. However, there is a difference between them. Brute force is literally trying ALL possible combination across options. On the other hand, Backtracking is to try, change the variable when it does not work, and then continue till when it finds the solution.&nbsp;</p><p class="">For example, if I have a set of door keys and need to find a toy in my friends\' house. However I am standing in front of 4 houses&nbsp; on a street, which my friend located by the pin on google map. I am not sure which house is my friends\'. In this case, I need to first try a different key to open the house door. We can try one house door by inserting all keys till I find the house. However, once I found the house, I do not have to try other rooms in the other house which is not my friend\'s house.&nbsp;</p><p>Another example is Sudoku. When we try to solve Sudoku, we use backtracking algorithm.&nbsp;</p><p><br></p><p>***</p><p>Grammarly: 0</p><p>Word of the day:&nbsp;impetus (a driving force, impulse)</p>\r\n        \r\n    \r\n    ',

When you use a microphone in a room&nbsp;and get too chockablock to the speaker, you might hear the extraordinary high pitch sound.&nbsp;</p><p><br></p><h3>Alcoholic</h3><p>The same thing can happen if you are an&nbsp;alcoholic. When you drink a lot of alcohol, you will get a&nbsp;hangover. If you drink additional alcohol, you feel that your hangover seems to be mitigated. Your brain will learn and remember "oh, to ease the hangover, it is better to drink more alcohol." Go back to the beginning of the loop.&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p><br></p><h3>Good Habit</h3><p>Even a good habit can fall into the same bucket. When you eat healthier food&nbsp;or do an exercise, you get the better "feeling", which is not necessarily a better effect on your body. Your brain receives a&nbsp;good signal and remembers "it is better to do more!"&nbsp;</p><p><br></p><p>Addiction, bad habits, and good habits are a kind of similar loop but the important factor is <i>controllability</i>.   'content': '\r\n        <p>Today I am describing the algorithm, called <b>Divide and Conquer</b>, which makes&nbsp;us imagine&nbsp;cacophony colonial ages but this is more peaceful. This is 7th&nbsp;post based on Feynman Technique. I will explain the concept with a&nbsp;simple term as possible as if I explained to a 10-year-old kid.</p><p><br></p><p>The concept of Divide and Conquer is <i>work-sharing or parallel work</i>. If you have a large task to be done as a team, and we divide the task into smaller tasks for each member. Each member is working on an independent&nbsp;smaller task, and then after all of the smaller tasks are&nbsp;done,&nbsp; we collect the result from each member and summarize the result for the larger task.&nbsp;</p><p>One example would be the&nbsp;presidential election. To elect the one president in the country, we divide the region and select the representative for each state, and then we will determine the one president for the whole country.&nbsp;</p><p>This sounds similar to <a href="https://200wordsaday.com/words/ft6-dynamic-programming-87835c638d3e00e33">Dynamic Programming</a>&nbsp;but the difference between them is the&nbsp;overlap of work<b>&nbsp;</b>among smaller tasks. Dynamic Programming allows to overlap the task and reuse the result of sub-tasks. But the Divide and Conquer algorithm is not.&nbsp;<b>&nbsp;</b></p><p>***&nbsp;</p><p>Grammarly: 12</p><p>Word of the day:&nbsp;cacophony&nbsp;</p>\r\n    ',

  'title': 'FT6 Dynamic Programming',
  'content': '\r\n        <p>I am writing about <b>Dynamic Programming</b>&nbsp;as 6th Feynman Technique post today. When you hear about the word, do you come up with the questions like "what is that?", "Why dynamic?",&nbsp; "Are there any static programming"? etc. I hope I can answer these questions today.</p><p><b>Dynamic Programming </b>is a way of solving a mathematical or computer science problem by decomposing one big problem into smaller pieces, obtaining solutions for each of smaller problems, and then composing these solutions into the solution for the big original problem.&nbsp;</p><p>For example, as a clerk at a&nbsp;Boba shop that teems people, let\'s say you need to count up the number of people in a line waiting for a cup of Boba tea. If you start to count from the beginning to the end one by one, you will get the number 78 at the end. Now, two people come into the queue. So what is the current number of people in the queue? The answer is 78+2 people. You do not have to start from scratch as long as you remember the number.&nbsp;</p><p>So, dynamic programming is similarly the way to save the complex computation by dividing the problem into smaller ones and memorizing the solution for smaller ones.&nbsp; &nbsp;</p><p>While I start to write this, I found "<a href="https://www.quora.com/How-should-I-explain-dynamic-programming-to-a-4-year-old/answer/Jonathan-Paulson">How should I explain dynamic programming to a 4-year-old?</a>", the amazing example of how to explain dynamic programming in Quora and tried to get the essence of&nbsp;it.&nbsp;</p><p>- Hiro</p><p>***&nbsp;</p><p>Grammarly: 7</p><p>Word of the day:&nbsp;teem</p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p>&nbsp;</p>\r\n    ',

  'content': '\r\n        \r\n        <p>I have been made a joke all the time by my friends and colleagues. I tend to take what they said literally, and easily tricked. On the other hand, I have a respect to those who can make a joke to ease the atmosphere in a team even if you are under stressful situation. So I am not a congenital joker but would like to improve it.&nbsp;</p><p>I assume those native jokers grows up in such an environment where you are trained and had repeatedly-embeded lessens in their conversastions in their life. But I was not. So I need finicky steps to get better.&nbsp;</p><p>Today I will break down what makes people laughed. Here is a good material for me:&nbsp;<a href="https://www.standupcomedyclinic.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/laughter-triggers.pdf">laughter-triggers.pdf&nbsp;</a>from&nbsp;<a href="www.standupcomedyclinic.com">www.standupcomedyclinic.com</a></p><p><br></p><p>There are 8 elements to trigger laghter:</p><ul><li>Surprise<br></li><li>Embarrassment</li><li>Recognition</li><li>Incongruity</li><li>Release</li><li>Superiority</li><li>Ambivalence</li><li>Configurational</li></ul><p><br></p><h3>Suprise</h3><p><b>Suprise</b> is about tricking people to think of something in a certain way, and at the end, it will be flipped in an unexpected way. It is like a magic where the audience was distracted or guided in one hand while a magician is doing something in behind and thne make something surprise at the end as the audience did not expect.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p><br></p><h3>Embarrassment</h3><p>We tend to langh at ourselves to disguise our <b>embarrassment</b>. For example, if you said to your friend confidently "The origin of Pizza is US!!", and by looking at Wiki together, it turned out that you are wrong. Then you might grin to release your embarrased emotion.&nbsp;</p><p>In addition, when you see this embarrassment in others and had similar situation before, people also tend to laugh since they can understand and feel sympathy for what is going in their mind.&nbsp;</p><p>Here is a example of type of embarrasment:</p><ul><li>Personal weakness impacting on our dignity</li><li>Failures</li><li>Private concerns<br></li><li><p>Sexual situations</p></li></ul><p>To identify your weakness that can be used for your joke, the following could be good start: clumsiness, difficulty in communicating with the opposite sex, weak, making a mistake, broke, procrastinate, slob, not punctual, overwight, skinny, addictive, bad grade etc.</p><p><br></p><h3>Incongruity</h3><blockquote>The definition of <b>incongruity</b> is when things don\'t match as they are expected to</blockquote><p>To create incongruity, we need to mislead the hearer or audience to think in a certain way. Then the setting will be flipped. One example from Groucho Marx is&nbsp;</p><p><br></p><blockquote>"One morning I shot an elephant in my pajamas. How he got in my pajamas, I don\'t know"</blockquote><p><br></p><p>I did not get this joke for a quite long time. Let me explain it line by line.&nbsp;</p><p>The first sentence is setting up the theme where the main character is. With the combination of "morning" and \'in my pajamas\', people may think he is in a bed and wearing a pajamas, and this elephant is about the character printed in a pajamas.&nbsp;</p><p>The next sentence turn the situation up side down.&nbsp;People normally do not imagine the elephants wearing a pajama but "how he got into my pajamas" indicates that the elephant was actually wearing the pajamas. This is the incongruity since the combination of elephan and pajama is unexpected match.&nbsp;</p><p>According to Victor Raskin, one of the typical incongruity combination is:&nbsp;</p><ul><li>good and bad<br></li><li>dead and&nbsp;alive</li><li>vulgar and non-vulgar</li><li>rich and poor</li><li>high and low</li></ul><p><br></p><p>***&nbsp;</p><p>Grammarly: 0</p><p>Word of the day:&nbsp;finicky</p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p>\r\n        \r\n    \r\n    \r\n    ',

  'title': 'FT5 Greedy Algorithm',

Because of this short-term thinking, this is <i>not</i> necessarily <i>the</i> <i>best</i> way in a long-run but it should be&nbsp;<i>okay</i> quality.&nbsp;</p><p>Greedy algorithm can be used for job scheduling problem.&nbsp;</p><p>For example, we have 5 different type of whole cakes with different price and the date to be consumed by as follows:</p><ul><li>cheese cake ($50): 1 day left<br></li><li>short cake ($60): 3 days left<br></li><li><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mont_Blanc_(dessert)">mont blanc</a> ($120): 1 days left (by the way, this is my favorite cake)</li><li>tiramisu ($90): 2 days left</li><li>ice cream cake ($80): 3 days left</li></ul><p>In this example, let\'s assume we can only eat <b>1 whole case per day</b> and try to <b>reduce the waste of money</b> for simplicity although I do not like the idea to think of just money, not taste or joy of eating a dessert.</p><p><br></p><p>1. Not fool myself and not just make a similar post, I asked feedback from my colleague and discuss the contents to come up with the&nbsp;new version as below.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p><br></p><h3><b>Bayes theorem</b></h3><p>Bayes theorem helps us to improve and update the prior knowledge&nbsp;of some events based on other observation or findings. We are using this in daily life. For example, if it rains today, you will think it will rain tomorrow high likely in a rainy&nbsp;season.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p>Here is another example for a kid with using numbers.&nbsp;</p><p>Let\'s say a boy, named John, would like to know how his mom, Mary\'s,&nbsp; mood was.&nbsp;</p><ul><li>Her mood&nbsp;can be only in a&nbsp;"good" or "bad" mood.&nbsp;<br></li><li>Her activity can be only \'staying home\' or \'going out.\'</li></ul><p>Here are other conditions:&nbsp;</p><ul><li>John also knows overall 80% of the time Mary is in a good mood.&nbsp;&nbsp;<br></li><li>If she was in a \'good\' mood, she was also "going out" with 90% probability</li><li>If she was in a \'bad\' mood, she was likely \'staying home\' with 70% probability.</li></ul><p><br></p><p>So today John is coming back from school and ask if Mary was \'going out\' or \'staying home.\' Her answer was \'going out.\' Based on this new information, John will update the general knowledge "she is normally 80% in a good mood" as follows:</p><ul><li>"going out" and \'good mood\' can happen 0.8(80%) x 0.9(90%) = 0.72</li><li>"going out" in spite of being in \'bad mood\' can happen 0.2(20%) x 0.3(30%) = 0.03<br></li><li>The ratio of "going out" and "good mood" over "going out" regardless of her mood is 0.72 over 0.72 + 0.06, which is 72/78 almost 0.92 (92%)</li></ul><p>In conclusion, John can update the probability from 80% to 92% based on his new observation today.</p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p>&nbsp;</p><p><br></p><p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>\r\n        \r\n    ',

Today I will write about "Heap", which is one of the topics that is asked for <a href="https://200wordsaday.com/words/coding-questions-72975c566c7351437">coding question</a> I wrote here. Let me try to explain "Heap" as plain as possible.&nbsp;</p><p><br></p><h3>Tree</h3><p>Before going to explain heap, we actually need to know "tree" based data structure, where each information is connected like a tree, which consists of 2 components: a node and an edge. This is very useful to explain the hierarchical relationship like country, state, and county.</p><p>For example, United States of America has 50 states. Each state has multiple counties. In this case, we can think of the following tree structure. The most left is the highest level in this tree.</p><p>USA - Alabama - County A&nbsp;</p><p>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;- County B</p><p>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; - Alaska&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;- County C</p><p>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;- County D</p><p>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;- County E</p><p><br></p><h3>Heap</h3><p>So now let\'s go back to "Heap." "Heap" is a type of tree meeting with the following certain conditions:</p><ol><li>each node has only but always two nodes</li><li>each node has a number information</li><li>a higher node has always bigger&nbsp;or always smaller  number.&nbsp; &nbsp;<br></li></ol><p>For example, there is a three-layer tree where each node has a number as below.</p><p>1 - 2 - 5<br>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; - 8<br>&nbsp; &nbsp;- 4 - 7<br>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; - 10</p><p>The top layer is the node with 1, which has two nodes meeting with Condition 1. All of the nodes has the number information, which meets with Condition 2. Last but not least, the higher node, 1 is bigger than either of nodes blongs to 1. The same rule can be applied for node 2 and 4 since their nodes has bigger values.&nbsp;</p><p><br></p><p>*****&nbsp;</p><p>Feynman techniques is working well. The decomposing the abstruse word into plain can be the process of understanding. In addition, I can remember more clearly what is the concept of topics. This could be a great chunk of drafts for my technical blog in the future if I continue to write like this.&nbsp;</p><p>Grammarly correction: 2</p><p>Word of the day:&nbsp;abstruse</p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p>&nbsp;&nbsp;</p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p>\r\n        \r\n    \r\n    \r\n    ',

  'content': '\r\n        \r\n        \r\n        \r\n        \r\n        \r\n        \r\n        <p>As I mentioned in the post "<a href="https://200wordsaday.com/words/feynman-technique-59835c4eae1a73414">Feynman Technique</a>", I would like to try to explain some of the concepts with plain and simple words as much as possible to test my understanding as if I explain it to my kid.&nbsp;</p><p>The first one is "Bayes Theorem."</p><p><br></p><h3>Bayes theorem</h3><p>Bayes theorem helps us to calculate the probability of what happen<b>ed in the past based on the current findings.&nbsp;</b>&nbsp;</p><p>For example, hey kid, let\'s say you would like to know how mom\'s mood was today based on her face and her activity now after you come back from school. If she was in a good mood, she is "going out" with 80% probability, 8 times out of 10 times. On the other hand, if she was in a bad mood, she is "staying home" with 70% chances, 7 times out of 10 times. Overall she is in a good mood&nbsp;with 90%. In this setting, if you see your mom is coming from outside and see she was going out, how likely do you think she was and is in a good mood?&nbsp;</p><ul><li>The event of&nbsp; "she is going out"&nbsp;8 / 10 and "in a good mood"&nbsp; 9/10 = 72 / 100<br></li><li>The event of "she is going out" 8 / 10 but "in a bad mood" 1 - 9/10 = 8 / 100</li></ul><p>So if you add up the two type of events, the chance of "going out" is 72 / 100 + 8/100 = 80/100.&nbsp;</p><p>Within this event, the ratio of the even when she is in a good mood" or "in a bad mood" is (72/100) ➗ (80/100) = 72/80 = 9/10. So you see that she was going out, more likely she is in a good mood. Does it match with your intuition?&nbsp;</p><p><br></p><p>I hope my kid will understand with this explanation.</p><p>When reading my writing above, the shaky area or one using a lot of technical terms is around probability and math. Also, I can add a more good explanation for how to calculate the ratio of she was going out.&nbsp;</p><p><br></p><p>Let me know where you think the shaky area is.</p><p>- Hiro</p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p>&nbsp;</p><p><br></p><p><br></p><p><br></p>\r\n    \r\n    \r\n    \r\n    \r\n    \r\n    \r\n    ',

If one cannot come up with an appropriate word, the word was already said by others or it is too slow to ride on the rhythm, the one loss. The loser will start the next round by giving a new category and so on.</p><p>For example, let\'s say we have 6 people and the first person gives the theme "animal." Then the following person says \'elephant\', the next will do with \'monkey\', and so on over rhythmical claps.&nbsp;</p><p><br></p><p>The tip for this game is very simple. Before your turn comes, you need to come up with at least <b>TWO</b> words in your mind. Even if your previous person takes one of your words right before your turn, you can choose the other one.&nbsp;</p><p><br></p><p>For 200wordaday, if we can have at least two posts as a draft, you can keep your streaks. Out[17]:

This post is quite similar to what I wrote yesterday "How to write a technical book" but a book is different from a blog. So today I will summarize some articles related to the way of writing a technical blog. 


How to find a topic

What to write? No topic to write... but you can write about

  • what you were stuck in a job
  • what you helped others 
  • pull request you made
  • lectures or conferences you attended
  • summarize what you did in a daily job
  • translate the foreign language into another language
  • read and break down an open source project or code
  • development methodology you are working on 

Whenever you find "issues", "needs", "help", they could be potential contents as long as we have the desire to share them with others. Or it is okay just for your note.


Flor of writing a blog

  1. Find a potential topic 
    If you cannot find by googling, it might be very valuable. 
  2. Determine the target audience
    Is it for beginners or experts? What do you want the reader to do after reading? 
  3. Finish writing 
    "Done is better than perfect"
  4. Create a title
    Spend more time on the most exposed part, which is a title. Come up with 30 relevant words and try a different combination of them accounting for the audience.
  5. Read and revise over and over
    You can read it one-day later. 
  6. Post it
  7. Share it

Mindset

  • "Not only smart people write a blog or book. It is equally important to write it from a beginners' perspective. It is also an ability to find it difficult"


***

To build a habit, I found it very powerful to have an appropriate mindset and the right strategy. That was an aha moment for me when I read and wrote about "On Writing Well by William".

I unconsciously thought the writing was not that hard but in reality, it was hard. This gap between my unconscious expectation and the reality generated the mental blocker.

In addition, once you know some tips to continue your training, it could become a much lower bar to pass and make it sustainable mentally and physically.
